title: North Korea Offers to Restart Nuclear Talks With U.S.
text:
SEOUL—North Korea vowed to reconvene nuclear talks with Washington later this month and signaled it was ready to engage in comprehensive discussions, a pledge that was followed hours later by the test-firing of two short-range projectiles.

Pyongyang, in a Tuesday state-media report on Tuesday, said it was ready for talks with the U.S. about relinquishing the regime’s nuclear arsenal. The remarks were attributed to First Vice Minister Choe Son Hui, one of the Kim regime’s most prominent interlocutors with the U.S. Ms. Choe said formal nuclear talks would occur at a yet-to-be-determined time and place in late September.

“I think the U.S. has since had enough time to find the calculation method that it can share with us,” Ms. Choe was quoted as saying.

President Trump, speaking to reporters Monday on his way to a rally in North Carolina, said he had seen Pyongyang’s state-media report about a potential meeting. “We will see what happens, but I always say having meetings is a good thing, not a bad thing,” Mr. Trump said.

Nuclear talks have remained gridlocked since the two sides left February’s Vietnam summit without a deal. North Korea has responded with repeated short-range missile tests and angry missives in state media directed at U.S. policy and senior officials.

Mr. Trump and North Korean leader Kim Jong Un held an impromptu June 30 meeting, agreeing to restart official denuclearization talks. But no formal talks have occurred in the ensuing two months.

North Korea’s launch of two short-range projectiles early Tuesday was its eighth test since July 25. The missiles were launched from the Kaecheon area of the North’s South Pyongan province, the first at 6:53 a.m. local time and the second 19 minutes later, according to Seoul’s military. The projectiles flew about 205 miles, though Seoul did not specify where they landed. The Kim regime last test-fired a weapon on Aug. 24.

“We urge North Korea to immediately halt acts that escalate tensions,” South Korea’s military said in a statement.

In Washington, a senior administration official said the U.S. was aware of the reported launch, and would continue to monitor the situation and coordinate with regional allies.

Secretary of State Mike Pompeo said Sunday he hopes denuclearization talks with North Korea will resume “in the coming days or perhaps weeks.”

In an appearance on ABC’s “This Week,” Mr. Pompeo said the administration is disappointed that Mr. Kim has continued to conduct short-range missile tests, but said the North Korean leader “has not yet violated” his commitment to Mr. Trump. He didn’t address the fact that the tests violate United Nations Security Council resolutions, according to many weapons experts.

The Japanese Defense Ministry said the missiles didn’t land in the nation’s territorial waters or its wider exclusive economic zone. None of North Korea’s recent missile launches have done so. Pyongyang’s state media didn’t have an immediate comment.

In a rare policy speech in April, Mr. Kim warned the U.S. to shift its negotiating stance by year’s end. The two sides left Vietnam after an abrupt breakdown in talks that revealed wide disagreements over how, and when, the North should surrender its nuclear weapons program.

But Mr. Kim knows Mr. Trump represents his best chance for a nuclear deal—and time may be running out as the president turns increasingly to his re-election campaign, said Jean H. Lee, director of the Korea program at the Wilson Center, a non-partisan think tank in Washington.

“The North Koreans aren’t sure which of its usual tactics — charm or threats—will be more effective in gaining leverage with Washington right now, so they’re doing a little of both,” Ms. Lee said.

The North’s pair of Tuesday moves, one for diplomacy and another for provocation, is another example of how Pyongyang has been the initiator with Washington, security experts said. After the two countries’ leaders held their June 30 meeting, the U.S. has repeatedly said it was ready to sit down with the North.

But the Kim regime continued to take an angry stance for much of July and August over joint U.S.-South Korea military exercises that the North perceived as a threat. Those maneuvers ended late last month.

“North Korea times things on its terms, reaches out on its terms, and raises tensions on its terms,” said Mintaro Oba, a former State Department official involved in North Korea policy.

Talks between the U.S. and North Korea raised hopes that Kim Jong Un will stop developing or even surrender his nuclear weapons. But security experts point to satellite images that they say show North Korea ramping up production of its arsenal over the past year. Photo composite: Sharon Shi

—Courtney McBride in Washington and Alastair Gale in Tokyo contributed to this article.

Write to Timothy W. Martin at timothy.martin@wsj.com and Andrew Jeong at andrew.jeong@wsj.com
